para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Accredited educational program” means a program accredited by The Commission on Accreditation of Allied Health Education Programs (CAAHEP), or its successor accrediting agency.
“Board” means the State Board of Physicians.
“Certified clinical perfusionist” means an individual holding a certificate issued by the national certifying board.
“Certification” means recognition of an individual who has satisfied certain standards required by the national certifying board.
“Committee” means the Perfusion Advisory Committee established under Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-05, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Conversion” means changing a license from licensed perfusionist-basic to licensed perfusionist-advanced.
“Disciplinary panel” means a panel established under Health Occupations Article, §14-401, Annotated Code of Maryland, which:
Is composed of 11 Board members; and
Addresses:
Complaints and disciplinary actions against licensed physicians and allied health professionals;
Initial licensure decisions; and
Postdisciplinary licensure reinstatements.
“Immediately available direction” means the responsibility of a licensed physician to provide necessary direction for a licensed perfusionist in person, by telephone, or by other electronic means.
“Joint Commission” means the organization formerly known as the Joint Commission on the Accreditation of Health Care Organizations.
“License” means a license issued by the Board to practice perfusion.

“Licensed perfusionist” means a perfusionist who is licensed by the Board, in accordance with Health Occupations Article, Title 14, Subtitle 5E, Annotated Code of Maryland, to practice perfusion as a:
Licensed perfusionist-advanced; or
Licensed perfusionist-basic.
“Licensed perfusionist-advanced” means an individual who is licensed by the Board as a perfusionist based on current certification as a certified clinical perfusionist.
“Licensed perfusionist-basic” means an individual who:
Is licensed by the Board as a perfusionist for a limited time based on graduation from an accredited perfusion educational program; and
Has not yet passed the national certifying examinations given by the national certifying board.
“Licensed physician” means a physician licensed by the Board.
“National Certifying Board” means the American Board of Cardiovascular Perfusion or its successor.
“National certifying examinations” means the two examinations given by the national certifying board.
“On-site direction” means the responsibility of a licensed physician to provide necessary direction for a licensed perfusionist when the physician is:
Physically present in the procedure room or in the facility; and
Able to respond if the perfusionist needs assistance during a procedure.
Practice Perfusion.

“Practice perfusion” means to perform the functions necessary for the support, treatment, measurement, or supplementation of the cardiovascular, circulatory, or respiratory systems, or other organs to ensure the safe management of physiologic functions by monitoring and analyzing the parameters of the systems under an order and the supervision of a licensed physician.
“Practice perfusion” includes:
Cardiopulmonary bypass for adult, pediatric, and neonatal patients;
Extracorporeal circulatory support for renal, neurological, hepatic, and vascular surgery;
Extracorporeal resuscitation;
Extracorporeal circulation for long-term support of failing respiratory or cardiac function;
Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation;
Extracorporeal carbon dioxide removal;
Myocardial protection;
Perfusion-assisted direct coronary artery bypass;
Hemofiltration and hemodialysis;
Anticoagulation and hemostasis monitoring, analysis, and intervention;
Thermal regulation;
Blood gas and blood chemistry monitoring, analysis, and intervention;
Physiological monitoring, analysis, and intervention;
Administration of blood components and pharmaceuticals;
Administration of anesthetic agents through a heart lung machine at the direction of an anesthesiologist;
Ventricular assist device and mechanical circulatory support management;
Intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation;
Temporary pacemaker management;
Periodic flow augmentation therapy;
Autotransfusion;
Platelet gel production, autologous hemocyte tissue matrix production;
Nondifferentiated progenitor cell harvest bone marrow aspirate concentration;
Acute normovolemic hemodilution;
Isolated limb or organ delivery of chemotherapeutics, progenitor cells, gene therapy vectors, and other items;
Organ procurement and preservation;
Thermogenic lavage;
Electrophysiological analysis;
Therapeutic hyperthermia;
Intravascular membrane oxygenation; and
Renal perfusion.
“Student” means an individual who, in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-09(c), Annotated Code of Maryland, is:
Enrolled in an accredited educational program to qualify for a license; and
Performing perfusion services within the accredited program under the supervision of a licensed perfusionist and without compensation.

“Supervision” means the responsibility of a licensed physician to exercise on-site direction or immediately available direction for a licensed perfusionist to ensure the safety and welfare of patients during the course of perfusion.
The Board shall appoint members of the Committee as follows:
Three individuals who are licensed perfusionists-advanced and who:
Are certified by a National Certifying Board; and
Have a minimum of 2 years of perfusion experience.
Three physicians, at least one of whom:
Performs cardiac or cardio-thoracic surgery; or
Is a cardiac or cardio-thoracic anesthesiologist; and
One consumer member who:
Shall be a member of the general public; and
May not:
Practice, or ever have practiced perfusion, or any other health care profession;
Be, or ever have been, in training to practice perfusion or any other health care profession;
Have a household member who is a health care professional or is in training to be a health care professional;
Participate, or ever have participated, in a commercial or professional field related to perfusion;
Have a household member who participates in a commercial or professional field related to perfusion;
Have had, within 2 years before appointment, a financial interest in a person regulated by the Board; or
Have had, within 2 years of appointment, a financial interest in the provision of goods or services to perfusionists or to the field of perfusion.
Chair.
The Committee shall elect a chair from among its members.
The chair shall serve for 2 years.
Tenure.
The term of a member is 3 years.
The terms of the members are staggered.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
An individual may be reappointed for a second 3-year term, but the individual may not serve more than two consecutive 3-year terms.
The terms of the initial members of the Perfusion Advisory Committee shall expire as follows:
Two members in 2013;
Two members in 2014; and
Three members in 2015.
Vacancy.
If a vacancy occurs, the Board shall appoint a new member to serve.
The successor member shall only serve for the remainder of the term, unless reappointed.
Quorum.
A majority of the members then serving on the Committee is a quorum.
Business may not be conducted at a Committee meeting unless there is a quorum.
The Committee shall develop and make recommendations to the Board in any matter related to regulating the practice of perfusion in the State.
The Board shall:
Consider all recommendations of the Committee; and
Provide the Committee with an annual report on disciplinary matters involving licensees.

section.heading: Qualifications for Licensure as a Perfusionist.

para.text: The Board shall license an individual if the individual meets the requirements of §§B and C of this regulation.
An individual applying for a license shall:
Complete an application on a form supplied by the Board;
Pay the required application fee set by the Board in Regulation .13 of this chapter;
Be 18 years old or older;
Be of good moral character;
Demonstrate spoken and written competency in English by any of the following:
Documentation of graduation from a recognized English-speaking high school or undergraduate school after at least 3 years of enrollment;
Documentation of graduation from a recognized English-speaking professional school; or
Documentation of receiving a grade of at least:
26 on the “Speaking Section” of the Internet-based Test of English as a Foreign Language; and
79 on the total score of the Internet-based Test of English as a Foreign Language;

If applicable, provide documentation of licensure, certification, or registration from all states and jurisdictions where the applicant has ever held a license, certificate, or registration in any health profession;
Have no history of public disciplinary action taken, or pending, against any license currently or previously held or expired; and
Complete a criminal history records check in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §14-308.1, Annotated Code of Maryland.
An applicant for a license as:

A perfusionist-basic shall submit satisfactory evidence of graduation from a perfusion educational program that is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of the Allied Health Education Program, or the Commission’s predecessor or successor;
A perfusionist-advanced shall submit satisfactory evidence of current national certification from the National Certifying Board.

section.heading: Renewal and Reinstatement of Licensure as a Perfusionist-Advanced.

para.text: Renewal Notice. At least 1 month before the license expires, the Board shall send a renewal notice to the licensed perfusionist-advanced that states:
The date on which the current license expires;
The date by which the renewal application shall be received by the Board for the renewal to be issued and mailed before the license expires; and
The amount of the renewal fee set by the Board in Regulation .13 of this chapter.
Renewal.
The term of a license issued by the Board may not exceed 3 years.

The Board may not renew a license until the Comptroller of Maryland has verified that the individual has paid all undisputed taxes and unemployment insurance contributions, or arranged for repayment, as required by COMAR 10.31.02.
An individual licensed as a perfusionist-basic may not renew the license.
An individual who has been licensed by the Board as a perfusionist-advanced may renew the license every 2 years on or before the date specified by the Board by:
Submitting a renewal application online or on a form supplied by the Board;
Paying the required renewal fee set by the Board in Regulation .13 of this chapter;
Attesting to current certification by the National Certifying Board; and
Being of good moral character.
Reinstatement. The Board shall reinstate the license of a perfusionist-advanced who has failed to renew the license for any reason if the perfusionist-advanced:
Completes a reinstatement application on a form supplied by the Board;
Meets any additional requirements set by the Board for reinstatement of a license;
Pays the required reinstatement fee and any other applicable fees set by the Board;
Is of good moral character; and
Completes a criminal history records check in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §14-308.1, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Reinstatement of a Revoked License.
On the application of an individual whose license has been revoked, the Board, on the affirmative vote of a majority of the quorum, may in its discretion reinstate a revoked license.
When a time period is not stated in an order for revocation:
The Board may not entertain an application for post-disciplinary reinstatement until at least 3 years after the date of the order; and
A revocation of a license may not be for less than 1 year.
The Board may not entertain an application for post-disciplinary reinstatement after an order of revocation unless:
Any time period stated in the order has expired;
Any condition set out in the order has been fulfilled;
The applicant has filed a formal application and paid the fee set by the Board in Regulation .13 of this chapter; and
The applicant meets all of the requirements for reinstatement set out in §D of this regulation.
The Board shall entertain applications for reinstatement pursuant to the procedures and standards of COMAR 10.32.02.06B.
The Board may not entertain applications for reinstatement if a revocation is permanent.
Application.
The continuing education requirements apply to all renewal applications.
The Board may not renew or reinstate the license of a perfusionist-advanced unless the perfusionist-advanced has met the requirements for continuing education described in §B of this regulation.
Requirements. A licensed perfusionist-advanced shall meet continuing education requirements sufficient to maintain current national certification from the National Certifying Board.
Documentation of Continuing Education Credits. A current certificate from the national certifying board will serve as documentation of continuing education credits earned.

Subject to the hearing provision of Health Occupations Article, §14-405, Annotated Code of Maryland, the disciplinary panel may deny a license to any applicant, reprimand any licensee, place any licensee on probation, or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee:
Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a license for the applicant or licensee or for another;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a license;
Is guilty of unprofessional or immoral conduct in the practice of perfusion;
Is professionally, physically, or mentally incompetent;
Abandons a patient;
Is habitually intoxicated;
Is addicted to, or habitually abuses, any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance as defined in Criminal Law Article, §5-101, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Provides professional services while:
Under the influence of alcohol; or

Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance as defined in Criminal Law Article, §5-101, Annotated Code of Maryland, or any other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;
Promotes the sale of services, drugs, devices, appliances, or goods to a patient so as to exploit the patient for financial gain;
Willfully makes or files a false report or record in the practice of perfusion;
Willfully fails to file or record any report as required under law, willfully impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of a report, or induces another to fail to file or record a report;
Breaches patient confidentiality;

Pays or agrees to pay any sum or provide any form of remuneration or material benefit to any person for bringing or referring a patient or accepts or agrees to accept any sum or any form of remuneration or material benefit from an individual for bringing or referring a patient;
Knowingly makes a misrepresentation while practicing perfusion;
Knowingly practices perfusion with an unauthorized individual or aids an unauthorized individual in the practice of perfusion;
Knowingly delegates a perfusion duty to an unlicensed individual;
Offers, undertakes, or agrees to cure or treat disease by a secret method, treatment or medicine;

Is disciplined by a licensing or disciplinary authority or is convicted or disciplined by a court of any state or country or is disciplined by any branch of the United States uniformed services or the US Department of Veterans Affairs for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes;
Fails to meet appropriate standards for the delivery of perfusion services;
Knowingly submits false statements to collect fees for which services are not provided;

Has been subject to investigation or disciplinary action by a licensing or disciplinary authority or by a court of any state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Board’s disciplinary statutes; and has:
Surrendered the license, if any, issued by the state or country; or
Allowed the license, if any, issued by the state or country to expire or lapse;
Knowingly fails to report suspected child abuse in violation of Family Law Article, §5-704, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Sells, prescribes, gives away, or administers drugs for illegal or illegitimate medical purposes;
Practices or attempts to practice beyond the authorized scope of practice;
Is convicted of or pleads nolo contendere to a felony or to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside;

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional services for which the licensee is licensed and qualified to render because the individual is HIV positive;

Practices or attempts to practice a perfusion procedure or uses or attempts to use perfusion equipment if the applicant or licensee has not received education and training in the performance of the procedure or the use of the equipment; or
Fails to cooperate with a lawful investigation of the Board.
Fails to complete a criminal history records check in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §14-308.1, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Crimes of Moral Turpitude.

On the filing of certified docket entries with the Board by the Office of the Attorney General, the disciplinary panel shall order the suspension of a license if the licensee is convicted of, or pleads guilty or nolo contendere with respect to, a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside.

After completion of the appellate process, if the conviction has not been reversed or the plea has not been set aside with respect to a crime involving moral turpitude, the disciplinary panel shall order the revocation of a license on the certification by the Office of the Attorney General.

Unless the disciplinary panel agrees to accept the surrender of a license, a licensed perfusionist may not surrender the license nor may the license lapse by operation of law while the licensee is under investigation or while charges are pending against the licensee.

Except as otherwise provided in Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-01(g), Annotated Code of Maryland, an individual may not practice, attempt to practice, or offer to practice perfusion in this State unless licensed to practice perfusion by the Board.
An individual who violates any provision of this chapter is subject to a civil fine of not more than $5,000 to be levied by the disciplinary panel.
The Board shall pay any penalty collected under this regulation into the Board of Physicians Fund.
A. Complaints alleging prohibited conduct shall be referred to the disciplinary panel to be investigated according to the disciplinary panel’s procedures.

A hearing on charges issued under Regulation .14 of this chapter or Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16(a), Annotated Code of Maryland, shall be held in accordance with the hearing provisions of Health Occupations Article, §14-405, Annotated Code of Maryland.

Proceedings for crimes of moral turpitude under Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16 (c), Annotated Code of Maryland, or Regulation .14B of this chapter, shall be held in accordance with COMAR 10.32.02.08.
Appeals from a final Board decision shall be taken in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-17, Annotated Code of Maryland.
General Application of Sanctioning Guidelines.
Sections A and B of this regulation and Regulation .19 of this chapter do not apply to offenses for which a mandatory sanction is set by statute or regulation.

Except as provided in §B of this regulation, for violations of Health Occupations Article §14-5E-16 Annotated Code of Maryland, listed in the sanctioning guidelines, the disciplinary panel shall impose a sanction not less severe than the minimum listed in the sanctioning guidelines nor more severe than the maximum listed in the sanctioning guidelines for each offense.
Ranking of Sanctions.
For the purposes of this regulation, the severity of sanctions is ranked as follows, from the least severe to the most severe:
Reprimand;
Probation;
Suspension; and
Revocation.
A stayed suspension in which the stay is conditioned on the completion of certain requirements is ranked as probation.
A stayed suspension not meeting the criteria for §A(3)(b) of this regulation is ranked as a reprimand.

A fine listed in the sanctioning guidelines may be imposed in addition to, but not as a substitute for a sanction. If a fine is listed, then at least the minimum fine will be imposed in addition to the sanction.
The imposition of a fine does not affect the making of the sanction.
The disciplinary panel may impose more than one sanction, provided that the most severe sanction neither exceeds the maximum nor is less than the minimum sanction permitted in the chart.
Any sanction may be accompanied by conditions reasonably related to the offense or to the rehabilitation of the offender. The inclusion of conditions does not change the ranking of the sanction.
If a licensee has violated more than one ground for discipline as set out in the sanctioning guidelines:
The sanction with the highest severity ranking should be used to determine which ground will be used in developing a sanction; and
The Board may impose concurrent sanctions based on other grounds violated.

Notwithstanding the sanctioning guidelines set forth in Regulation .19 of this chapter, in order to resolve a pending disciplinary action, the Board and the licensee may agree to a surrender of license or a consent order with terms and sanction agreed to by the Board, the administrative prosecutor, and the licensee.
Aggravating and Mitigating Factors.

Depending on the facts and circumstances of each case, and to the extent that the facts and circumstances apply, the Board may consider the aggravating and mitigating factors set out in §B(4) and (5) of this regulation and may in its discretion determine, based on those factors, that an exception should be made and that the sanction in a particular case should fall outside the range of sanctions listed in the sanctioning guidelines.
Nothing in this regulation requires the Board or an Administrative Law Judge to make findings of fact with respect to any of these factors.

The existence of one or more of these factors does not impose on the Board or an Administrative Law Judge any requirement to articulate its reasoning for not exercising its discretion to impose a sanction outside of the range of sanctions set out in the sanctioning guidelines.
Mitigating factors may include, but are not limited to, the following:
The absence of a prior disciplinary record;
The offender self-reported the incident;
The offender voluntarily admitted the misconduct, made full disclosure to the Board and was cooperative during the Board proceedings;
The offender implemented remedial measures to correct or mitigate the harm arising from the misconduct;
The offender made good faith efforts to make restitution or to rectify the consequences of the misconduct;
The offender has been rehabilitated or exhibits rehabilitative potential;
The misconduct was not premeditated;
There was no potential harm to patients or the public or other adverse impact; or
The incident was isolated and is not likely to recur.
Aggravating factors may include, but are not limited to, the following:
The offender has a previous criminal or administrative disciplinary history;
The offense was committed deliberately or with gross negligence or recklessness;
The offense had the potential for or actually did cause patient harm;
The offense was part of a pattern of detrimental conduct;
The offender committed a combination of factually discrete offenses adjudicated in a single action;
The offender pursued his or her financial gain over the patient’s welfare;
The patient was especially vulnerable;
The offender attempted to hide the error or misconduct from patients or others;
The offender concealed, falsified, or destroyed evidence or presented false testimony or evidence;
The offender did not cooperate with the investigation; or
Previous attempts to rehabilitate the offender were unsuccessful.
Offenses Related to Continuing Education Credits.
Willful Falsification.
If a licensee has willfully falsified an application with respect to continuing education credits, the licensee may be charged under one or more of the following, as appropriate:
Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16(a)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland;
Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16(a)(3), Annotated Code of Maryland;
Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16(a)(10), Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16(a)(11), Annotated Code of Maryland.
Upon finding a violation, the Board may impose any discipline authorized under Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16, Annotated Code of Maryland, and the sanctioning guidelines.
Licensees Previously Disciplined Under §C(1) of this regulation.

Upon a finding of a violation, the Board may impose any discipline authorized under Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16, Annotated Code of Maryland, and the sanctioning guidelines for a subsequent offense.
The Board may not apply the sanction described in §C(1) of this regulation in determining a sanction for a licensee previously disciplined for an offense related to continuing education credits.
Offenses Related to Clinical Activity.
Willful Falsification.
If a licensee has willfully falsified an application with respect to clinical activities, the licensee may be charged under one or more of the following, as appropriate:
Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16(a)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland;
Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16(a)(3), Annotated Code of Maryland;
Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16(a)(10), Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16(a)(11), Annotated Code of Maryland.
Upon a finding of a violation, the Board may impose any discipline authorized under Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16, Annotated Code of Maryland, and the sanctioning guidelines.
Licensees Previously Disciplined Under §D(1) of this regulation.
Upon a finding of a violation, the Board may impose any discipline authorized under Health Occupations Article, §14-5E-16, Annotated Code of Maryland, and the sanctioning guidelines.
The Board may not apply the sanction described in §D(1) of this regulation in determining as sanction for a licensee previously fined or disciplined for an offense related to criminal activities.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Approved naturopathic medical program” means a naturopathic medical education program:
In the United States that:
Provides the degree of Doctor of Naturopathy or Doctor of Naturopathic Medicine;
Offers a 4-year graduate level full-time didactic and supervised clinical training;

Is accredited or has achieved candidacy status for accreditation, by the council on naturopathic medial education or an equivalent federally and Board recognized accrediting body for naturopathic medical education programs; and

Is part of an institution of higher education that is either accredited, or is a candidate for accreditation, by a regional or national institutional accrediting agency recognized by the United States Secretary of Education;
In a diploma-granting, degree-equivalent college or university in Canada that:
Offers graduate level, full-time didactic and supervised clinical training; and

Is accredited, or has achieved candidacy status for accreditation, by the council of naturopathic medical education or an equivalent federally and Board recognized accrediting body for participation in government-funded student aid programs; or
Has provincial approval for participation in government-funded student aid programs.

“Articular manipulation” means manipulation of the joints up to but not including manipulation beyond the elastic limit and exclusive of low amplitude, high velocity thrusts, also known as Grade V manipulations.
“Attestation” means a statement of intent.
“Board” means the State Board of Physicians.
“Central Repository” means the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.

“Collaborate” means a cooperative relationship between naturopathic doctors and licensed physicians, which does not imply or create a supervisory relationship between the licensed physician and the naturopathic doctor.
“Collaboration and consultation agreement” means an agreement whereby a naturopathic doctor and physician will collaborate and consult regarding a patient’s care, but in which the:
Patient does not enter the care of the consulted physician;
Consultation does not create a physician-patient relationship; and
Consulted physician does not direct patient care or engage directly in the care of the patient.
“Committee” means the Naturopathic Medicine Advisory Committee.

“Consult” or “consultation” means a process whereby a naturopathic doctor seeks the advice or opinion of a licensed or certified health care provider as needed in the treatment of a patient, which may include discussion of the:
Patient’s diagnosis;
Differential diagnoses and diagnostic method;
Current naturopathic treatment;
Patient’s response thus far to naturopathic treatment;
Potential medical and other options outside the naturopathic doctors scope of practice that might benefit the patient;
Patient’s potential response to diagnostic and treatment options outside the naturopathic doctor’s scope of practice; and
Patient’s expected prognosis.
“Corrective and orthopedic gymnastics” means therapeutic exercises, stretching, and other movement therapies intended to promote healing and rehabilitation.
“Council” means the Naturopathic Doctors Formulary Council.
“Criminal history records check” means the performance of both a State criminal history check by the Central Repository, and a national criminal history check by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

“Criminal history records information” means information provided by the criminal history records check regarding an applicant’s criminal arrests, charges, and convictions, and the disposition of pending criminal charges.

“Diagnostic imaging” includes, but is not limited to, X-ray, ultrasound, mammogram, bone densitometry, computed tomography (CT scans), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI scans), endoscopic exam, and all other forms of nuclear imaging.

“Electromagnetic energy” means electric and magnetic energy administered through the use of a therapeutic device, including, but not limited to, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, microcurrent electrical muscle stimulation, diathermy, infrared, ultra-violet treatments, and other devices which utilize electrical or magnetic force for therapeutic effect.

“Electrotherapy” means treatment through application of electric energy administered through the use of therapeutic devices, including, but not limited to, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, microcurrent electrical neuromuscular stimulation, and other devices which utilize electrical force for therapeutic effect.
Goods.
“Goods” means items that can be sold.
“Goods” includes, but is not limited to, natural medicines referenced in Health Occupations Article, §14-5F—14(a)(3) and (4), Annotated Code of Maryland.
Hydrotherapy.
“Hydrotherapy” means external and internal applications of hot and cold water, ice, and steam for therapeutic purposes.
“Hydrotherapy” includes, but is not limited to, hot or cold compresses, hydrocollator packs, hot or cold baths or showers involving the full body or specific body parts.
“Licensed naturopathic doctor” means a naturopathic doctor who is licensed by the Board to practice naturopathic medicine.
“Mechanical sciences of healing” means techniques and therapies which attempt to promote healing via mechanical or physical applications.
“Mechanotherapy” means treatment by mechanical means including the use of durable medical and therapeutic devices.
“Natural medicine” means medicine derived from mineral, animal, or botanical origin.
“Naturopathic doctor” means an individual who practices naturopathic medicine.
Naturopathic Medicine.

“Naturopathic medicine” means the prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of human health conditions, injury, and disease using only patient education and naturopathic therapies and their therapeutic substances recognized by the council of naturopathic therapies and therapeutic substances recognized by the Council of Naturopathic Medical Education.
“Naturopathic medicine” includes:
Counseling;
The practice of the mechanical sciences of healing, including mechanotherapy, articular manipulations, corrective and orthopedic gymnastics, hydrotherapy, electrotherapy, and phototherapy; and
The practice of the material sciences of healing, including nutrition, phytotherapy, treatment by natural substances, and external applications.

“Naturopathic musculoskeletal mobilization” means the treatment by manual and other mechanical means of all body tissues exclusive of high-velocity thrusts at or beyond the end range of normal joint motion.
“Non-bona-fide treatment” means when:
A naturopathic doctor treats or examines a patient in a way that involves sexual contact when there is no medical reason for the procedure; or
The procedure falls outside a naturopathic doctor’s scope of practice.
“Phototherapy” means treatment through application of light, including visible light, ultraviolet light, infrared, natural sources of light, and artificial sources of light.
Physiological Function Tests.
“Physiological function tests” means all tests performed to assess and diagnose physiological processes in all bodily systems.
“Physiological function tests” include, but are not limited to, respiratory testing, heart rate, percent body fat, body composition, and others, as consistent with naturopathic medical education.
“Phytotherapy” means treatment by use of botanical medicines.
“Prescription drug” means any drug defined in the federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. §503(b), as amended, if the drug’s label is required to bear the statement “Rx only”.
“Sexually exploitative relationship” means a naturopathic doctor taking advantage of an unequal relationship between the naturopathic doctor and patient, staff member, or student.
“Therapeutic deception” means representation by a naturopathic doctor that sexual contact or sexual activity by or with a patient is consistent with or part of a patient’s treatment.
The Council consists of the following members:
The Deputy Secretary for Public Health Services or the Deputy Secretary’s designee; and
The following members, appointed by the Board:
Two individuals who:
Are licensed in the State as naturopathic doctors;
Practice naturopathic medicine in the State;
Are certified by the North American Board of Naturopathic Examiners; and
Have a minimum of 2 years experience;
Two licensed physicians who practice in the State;
One pharmacist who has a background in pharmacognosy and who practices in the State; and
One consumer of naturopathic services.
Term of Appointment—Naturopathic Doctors Formulary Council.
The term of an appointed member of the Council is 4 years and is staggered.
At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
An individual may be reappointed for a second 4-year term but may not serve more than two consecutive 4-year terms.
The terms of the initial members of the Naturopathic Doctors Formulary Council shall expire as follows:
One naturopathic doctor member;
One physician member; and
The consumer member; and
One naturopathic doctor member;
One physician member, and
The pharmacist member.

A member of the Council may not receive compensation as a member of the Council, but is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
The Board shall designate the chair of the Council, whose term of office of the chair is 2 years.
The Board shall provide staff for the Council.

section.heading: Naturopathic Doctors Formulary Council and Board Duties.

para.text: Council Duties.
The Council shall:
Develop and recommend to the Board a formulary for use by licensed naturopathic doctors;

Annually review the formulary adopted by the Board under §B(2) of this regulation to determine if any changes are necessary for compliance with current prescribing standards or the practice of naturopathic medicine;
Otherwise review the formulary at the direction of the Board; and
Make recommendations to the Board based on the reviews conducted under this regulation.
The Board shall adopt a formulary based on the Council's recommendations under this regulation.
Board Duties.
The Board may modify or reject any recommendation of the Council regarding the formulary.
The formulary adopted by the Board shall be in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §14-5F-04.1, Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: Collaboration and Consultation Agreement and the Written Attestation.

para.text: A collaboration and consultation agreement shall:
Include the name and license number of the physician with whom the applicant has the collaboration and consultation agreement;
State that the applicant will require patients to sign a consent form in plain language that:
The naturopathic doctor’s practice of naturopathic medicine is limited to the scope of practice identified in Health Occupations Article, §14-5F-14, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Describes the differences in scope of practice between naturopathic doctors and physicians;
State that naturopathic doctors shall refer patients to and consult with physicians and other health care providers licensed or certified under the Health Occupations Article as needed; and
State that in cases where the naturopathic doctor diagnoses a patient with a life threatening condition, the naturopathic doctor shall:
Counsel and discuss with the patient the potential benefits offered by other physicians or other healthcare professionals; and
Attempt to make the appropriate referral.
An applicant shall complete and submit to the Board a written attestation on a form supplied by the Board that states that the applicant has a collaboration and consultation agreement:
With a physician that is licensed in this State under Health Occupations Article, Title 14, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
That meets the requirements of §A of this regulation.
An applicant shall inform the physician named as a collaborating physician in the attestation that the physician has been named.
A licensee shall maintain a collaboration and consultation agreement that meets the requirements of this regulation in order to practice naturopathic medicine in the State.
A licensee shall comply with the requirements of the licensee’s collaboration and consultation agreement with a physician.
Renewals.
The Board may not renew a license until the Comptroller of Maryland has verified that the individual has paid all undisputed taxes and unemployment insurance contributions, or arranged for repayment.
The term of a license renewed by the Board is 2 years from the date of renewal.
A license expires at the end of its term unless the license is renewed as provided by the Board.
At least 1 month before the license expires, the Board shall send to the licensee a renewal notice that states:
The date on which the current license expires;
The date by which the renewal application shall be received by the Board for the renewal to be issued before the license expires; and
The amount of the renewal fee as specified in Regulation .20 of this chapter.
The Board shall renew the license of a licensee who:
Submits a renewal application on the form that the Board requires;
Pays a renewal fee as specified in Regulation .20 of this chapter;
Is otherwise entitled to be licensed;
Meets the continuing education requirements as set forth in Regulation 11 of this chapter;
Provides evidence of biennial cardiopulmonary resuscitation certification; and

Attests that the licensee has a current collaboration and consultation agreement with a physician licensed in the State that meets the requirements of Regulation .05 of this chapter at the time of renewal..
The failure to receive a renewal notice does not excuse a licensee from complying with §A(3) of this regulation.
Reinstatement of an Expired or Lapsed License. An individual applying for reinstatement of a license to practice naturopathic medicine who failed to renew for any reason shall:
Complete a reinstatement application on a form supplied by the Board;
Pay the Board the reinstatement fee set by the Board in accordance with Regulation .20 of this chapter;
Complete a criminal history records check in accordance with Health Occupations Article §14-308.1, Annotated Code of Maryland;

Provide documentation of completion of at least 50 hours of approved continuing education earned during the 2-year period preceding the date of the submission of the application for reinstatement; and

Attest that the licensee has a current collaboration and consultation agreement with a physician licensed in the State that meets the requirements of Regulation .05 of this chapter at the time of reinstatement.
Meet any additional requirements set by the Board for reinstatement of a license.
Reinstatement after Revocation of a License or After a Lapse in Renewal.
On the application of an individual whose license has been revoked, the disciplinary panel, on the affirmative vote of a majority of the quorum, may, in its discretion, reinstate a revoked license.

When a time period is not stated in an order for revocation, the disciplinary panel may not entertain an application for post-disciplinary reinstatement until at least 3 years after the date of the order.
The disciplinary panel may not entertain an application for post-disciplinary reinstatement after an order of revocation unless:
Any time period stated in the order has expired;
Any condition set out in the order has been fulfilled;
The applicant has filed a formal application and paid the fee set by the Board in Regulation .20 of this chapter; and
The applicant meets all of the requirements for reinstatement set out in §B of this regulation.
The disciplinary panel shall entertain applications for reinstatement pursuant to the procedures and standards of COMAR 10.32.02.06B.
A revocation of a license may not be for less than 1 year.
The disciplinary panel may not entertain applications for reinstatement if a revocation is permanent.
The applicant shall meet any additional requirements set by the Board for reinstatement of a license.
After the expiration date of the license, the naturopathic doctor is no longer licensed to practice naturopathic medicine.
Requirements. A licensed naturopathic doctor shall take at least 50 hours of continuing education credits during every 2-year renewal period:
For license renewal, preceding the expiration of the license for a naturopathic doctor; or
For license reinstatement, preceding the date of the submission of the application for reinstatement.
The courses selected shall be approved by any of the following:
The American Association of Naturopathic Physicians;
The Maryland Association of Naturopathic Physicians;
The Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education;
The Accreditation Council for Pharmacy Education;
The North American Naturopathic Continuing Education Accreditation Council; or
A naturopathic doctor’s licensing authority or professional association of another state which meets the standards adopted by the American Association of Naturopathic Physicians.

section.heading: Fees.
section.text: The following fees are applicable to naturopathic doctors:

para.text: Initial application fee — $790;
Renewal Fee:
Biennial license renewal fee — $486; and
The Maryland Health Care Commission fee as determined by Maryland Health Care Commission under COMAR 10.25.03;
License reinstatement fee—$700; and
Written verification fee—$50.

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This subtitle governs the licensure, practice, and discipline of nursing home administrators and assisted living managers in the State.

para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

“Administrator-in-training (AIT)” means an applicant approved by the Board to train to practice as a nursing home administrator in a nursing home under the supervision of a preceptor pursuant to this subtitle.
“Administrator-in-training (AIT) contract” means a document signed by an AIT and a preceptor which includes requirements of the AIT program.
“Administrator-in-training (AIT) program” means a Board-approved program which consists of practical training and experience in nursing home administration.

“Alternate assisted living manager” means an individual who is available to assume the duties of the licensed assisted living manager for a licensed assisted living program when the licensed assisted living manager is temporarily unavailable to perform the duties of an assisted living manager.
“Assisted living manager” means an individual who is:
Designated by an assisted living program to oversee the overall day-to-day operations of an assisted living program; and
Responsible for the duties set forth under COMAR 10.07.14.15.
Assisted Living Program.

“Assisted living program” means a residential or facility-based program for two or more residents that provides long-term housing and supportive services, supervision, personalized assistance, health-related services, or a combination of those that meets the needs of the individuals who are unable to perform or who need assistance in performing the activities of daily living or instrumental activities of daily living in a way that promotes optimum dignity and independence for the individuals.
“Assisted living program” does not include:
A nursing home as defined by Health-General Article, §19-1401, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A nursing facility as defined by Health-General Article, §19-301, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A State facility, as defined under Health-General Article, §10-101, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A program licensed or approved by the Department under Health-General Article, Title 7 or Title 10, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A hospice care program licensed by the Department under Health-General Article, Title 19, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Services provided by family members;
Services provided by a licensed residential service agency or licensed home health agency in an individual’s own home; or
A Certified Adult Residential Environment Program that is certified by the Department of Human Services under Human Services Article, §§6-508—6-513, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Board” means the State Board of Long-Term Care Administrators.
“Central Repository” means the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
“Department” means the Maryland Department of Health.
“Endorsement applicant” means an individual applying for a license to practice nursing home administration in the State who is licensed in another state to practice nursing home administration.
“Family” means:
A spouse;
A child;
A sibling;
A parent;
A grandparent;
A niece or nephew; or
An uncle or aunt.
“Family-owned or family-operated nursing facility” means a nursing home owned or operated by any one or more of the following relatives of the AIT:
A spouse;
A parent;
A child;
A sibling;
A grandparent;
A grandchild;
A stepparent;
A stepchild;
An uncle or aunt;
A first cousin;
A nephew or niece;
A father-in-law or mother-in law;
A son-in-law or daughter-in-law; or
A brother-in-law or sister-in-law.
“License” means, unless the context requires otherwise, official authorization issued by the Board to practice as:
A nursing home administrator under Health Occupations Article, Title 9, Subtitle 3, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
An assisted living manager under Health Occupations Article, Title 9, Subtitle 3A, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Licensee” means, unless the context requires otherwise, an individual licensed by the Board to practice as:
A nursing home administrator; or
An assisted living manager.

“National Association of Long Term Care Administrator Boards (NAB)” means the organization that commissions the services of a third-party administrator of the State and national examinations for long term care administrators.
“Nursing home” means a facility or institution as defined in Health Occupations Article, §9-101(i), Annotated Code of Maryland, and includes:
A comprehensive care facility or extended care facility which offers non-acute inpatient care to residents who:
Have a disease, chronic illness, condition, disability of advanced age, or terminal disease requiring maximal nursing care without continuous hospital services; and
Require medical services and nursing services rendered by or under the supervision of a licensed nurse together with convalescent, restorative, or rehabilitative services; and
A nursing facility as defined under federal or State law.
“Nursing home administrator” means an individual licensed by the Board, who:

Administers, directs, manages, supervises, or is in general administrative charge of a nursing home, whether or not the individual has an ownership interest in the facility, and whether or not the individual's functions and duties are shared with one or more individuals; or

Is in supervisory control over one or more nursing home administrators of one or more nursing homes and has authority to substitute the supervisor's judgment for that of the administrator of record in the day-to-day operation of the facility.
“Person” means any individual, guardian, personal representative, company, corporation, partnership, limited liability company, association, representative of any kind, or non-governmental entity.

“Practice of assisted living management” means the exercise of final authority of any act or in the making of any decision involved in the planning, organizing, directing, or controlling of the day-to-day operation of an assisted living program.

“Practice of nursing home administration” means the exercise of final authority of any act or in the making of any decision involved in the planning, organizing, directing, or controlling of the day-to-day operation of a nursing home.
“Preceptor” means an individual certified to serve as an instructor in an AIT program to be a nursing home administrator, pursuant to this subtitle.
“State standards exam” means an examination developed by the Board based on the following chapters:
COMAR 10.09.24; and
The Board shall exercise the powers provided by the laws of this State pertaining to the licensure, practice, and discipline of nursing home administrators and assisted living managers.
Board staff and designees of the Board:
May enter any nursing home and assisted living program in the State in order to carry out its functions; and
Shall have access to the records related to licensure of any nursing home and assisted living program in the State in order to carry out its functions.
The Office of Health Care Quality may assist the Board in carrying out its functions.
The Board has the authority to utilize consultant experts, as needed, in areas of its concern.

From time to time, the Board shall make and publish regulations for the execution and enforcement of the laws related to the licensure, license renewal, and discipline of nursing home administrators and assisted living managers.

section.heading: Severability.
section.text: If any provision of the regulations in this subtitle is declared unconstitutional or invalid, or the application of these regulations to any person or circumstances is held invalid, the applicability of the provision to other persons and circumstances and the constitutionality or validity of every other provision of these regulations is not to be affected.

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: This chapter governs nursing home administrator applicants and licensees in the State pursuant to Health Occupations Article, Title 9, Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, to qualify for an initial license to practice nursing home administration in the State, the applicant shall:
Be at least 21 years old;
Be of good moral character;
Submit to a State and national criminal history records check in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §9-302.1, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Obtain a passing score on the State standards exam;
Obtain a passing score on the national licensure exams provided by NAB; and
Except for an endorsement applicant, successfully complete the AIT program as set forth in Regulation .04 of this chapter.

The Board’s receipt of the State and national criminal history records check from the Central Repository, as provided in Health Occupations Article, §9-302.1(c), Annotated Code of Maryland, satisfies Health Occupations Article, §9-303(3), Annotated Code of Maryland.
The applicant shall submit to the Board:
The completed Board online application;
The application fee as set forth under COMAR 10.33.05.02D;
Satisfactory evidence that the applicant has a bachelor’s or master’s degree in:

Healthcare, health administration, or healthcare management, or the equivalent, with a concentration in healthcare administration or health administration or a master’s degree in business with a concentration in healthcare administration or health administration from an accredited college or university; or

A field other than as described in §C(3)(a) of this regulation and has completed within the last 5 years a minimum 100-hour course approved by the Board in healthcare administration or health administration;

Two letters of character reference, which are signed and dated within 3 months prior to the date of application, from individuals engaged in either business or professional work on company or business letterhead:
Who shall attest to the good moral character of the applicant; and
Which may not be those from current employers or members of the applicant's family; and
A passport type and size photograph of the applicant, which shall have been taken within 3 months prior to the date of application.
Except for an endorsement applicant, an applicant may take the State standards exam and NAB exams when the applicant has completed:
A minimum of 8 months of the full-time 12-month AIT program or its equivalent or 12 months of the 18-month part-time AIT program or its equivalent; and
The other requirements for licensure as specified in this regulation.
The 100-hour course for applicants with a bachelor’s or master’s degree in a field other than those described in §C(3)(a) of this regulation shall:
Contain the subject matter relating to healthcare or health administration set forth under Regulation .03A of this chapter; and
Be taken for credit for the purpose of initial licensure and be a course that has been approved by the Board.

An applicant who provides satisfactory evidence to the Board that the applicant is a registered nurse and who meets the requirements of Health Occupations Article, §9-302(f)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland, is not required to have a bachelor’s or master’s degree.

An application shall be void if an applicant fails to meet all the requirements for licensure within 2 years of receipt of the application by the Board. To pursue licensure after that time, the applicant shall:
Submit a new application; and
Meet the requirements for licensure that are in effect at the time of reapplication.
Subjects for Examination. The State standards exam and the NAB exams shall include, at a minimum, the following subjects:
Applicable standards of environmental health and safety;
Local health and safety regulations;
General administration;
Psychology of patient care;
Principles of medical care;
Personal and social care;
Therapeutic and supportive care and services in long-term care;
Departmental organization and management; and
Community interrelationships.
Scoring Examinations.
The passing score for licensure examinations for a license shall be determined by the Board.
The Board shall determine a method of scoring each part of the exams separately and shall apply that method uniformly to all applicants taking the exams.
Minimum Passing Scores. The following apply.
The NAB national exams—scale score of 113 on the:
NAB CORE exam; and
NAB NHA exam; and
The State standards exam—75 percent correct answers.
General Provisions.

An AIT program is a supervised 12-month full-time, or 18-month part-time, internship during which the AIT works under the guidance and supervision of a preceptor who is a licensed administrator that meets the qualifications set forth in Regulations .05 and .06 of this chapter.

The AIT program is a required phase of education consisting of both the supervised practice of nursing home administration in the environment of the nursing home, performing and participating in the day-to-day duties of each position, when legally permissible, in each of the following service areas:
Administration;
Business office;
Nursing;
Resident activities;
Social services;
Medical records;
Dietary services;
Maintenance;
Environmental services, including housekeeping and laundry;
Rehabilitation services; and
Quality assurance.

Prior to Board approval of the AIT program, the AIT applicant and preceptor shall develop an outline for the written course of instruction and dates of rotation schedule for the provision of practical training, experience, and learning situations that includes:
The 11 basic service areas set forth in §A(2) of this regulation;
The AIT's past experience and allocation of clinical experiences in the nursing home; and
Approval by the Board.
An AIT may not, during the normal working hours of the program, fill a specific, specialized position in the nursing home.
The AIT shall be exposed to all shifts during the AIT program.
If the AIT is a department head, notice shall be conspicuously posted in the nursing home stating who the acting department head will be while the AIT is performing training duties.

If an applicant does not meet all of the requirements for licensure after having completed 12 months in the full-time or 18 months in the part-time AIT program, the preceptor and applicant have the option to work out a plan satisfactory to the Board to continue studying in the AIT program beyond the 12 or 18 months until all the requirements are met.
The Board or Board committee shall interview each applicant and proposed preceptor, or preceptors, before the approval of an AIT program.
After the interview, the AIT and preceptor shall sign an AIT contract and submit it to the Board for consideration of approval.
The Board may approve the AIT program if it is satisfied that the background and circumstances of the applicant and preceptor, or preceptors, qualify them for the AIT program.
A change of preceptor may be authorized by the Board upon submission of:
Application by the proposed new preceptor;
Evidence satisfactory to the Board that the proposed preceptor is certified by the Board; and
A new signed AIT contract by the AIT and preceptor.

If a preceptor is found by the Board to have failed to provide adequate training, the Board may cancel the preceptor's authorization to serve as a preceptor for a period of time prescribed by the Board.
The AIT and preceptor shall comply with the AIT contract.

An individual duly registered as an AIT whose internship is interrupted by service in the armed forces of the United States shall be permitted to resume the internship without loss of credit at any time within 1 year after the date of the AIT's separation from active service.
Application Requirements.
The Board may approve an application for a nursing home AIT program only if it determines that the application contains satisfactory evidence that:
The applicant is at least 21 years old;
The applicant is of good moral character;
The applicant's training will be supervised by a Board-certified preceptor; and
The AIT program meets the other requirements set forth in this regulation.
The training proposed to be provided to the applicant shall be satisfactory to the Board.
The applicant shall participate in training provided in:
A nursing home licensed in the State, as defined in COMAR 10.33.01.02B; and
Not more than two licensed nursing homes in the State approved by the Board for training. If two nursing homes are utilized for training, one shall have at least 60 beds.

If there are subject areas as specified in the list of subjects provided in §A(2) of this regulation that are not available in the nursing home approved by the Board for training, the Board may require training in other facilities.
Credit for Prior Experience.

The AIT program is a minimum of 12 months for full-time programs or 18 months for part-time programs unless, upon request from the applicant to review prior work experience, the Board awards credit for prior experience within the last 5 years. The amount of credit awarded is at the discretion of the Board, based on an applicant’s work experience demonstrating exposure to the core of knowledge set forth in Regulation .04A(2) of this chapter, but may not exceed;
Six months for a hospital assistant administrator;
Eight months for a hospital administrator;
Six months for a nursing home assistant administrator;
Six months for a department head;
Three months for an Executive Director of a continuing care retirement community;
Three months for an assisted living manager;
Three months for a healthcare-related senior management official; or
Three months for a non-healthcare-related senior management official.
Qualifying Experience for Healthcare Related Professions in §C(1)(a)—(f) of this regulation. The minimum experience required for receiving credit towards the AIT program includes:
A minimum of 18 months as a full-time employee, with line responsibility for hiring, firing, budget, and supervision of at least one department comprised of ten or more employees; and
Reporting directly to the nursing home administrator or chief executive officer.

Qualifying Experience for Healthcare Related or Non-Healthcare Related Senior Management Official in §C(1)(g) and (h) of this regulation. The following requirements set the minimum experience required for receiving credit:
Minimum of 18 months as a full-time senior management official of a single nursing home or entity; and
Administrative responsibility for the total operation of the nursing home or entity and its multiple departments, as applicable.
Experience credit can be awarded on a month-to-month basis totaling 12 months for:
An individual who has worked as a licensed nursing home administrator in another state;
A resident or intern in a program offered by an accredited college or university for the purpose of satisfying the requirements for a baccalaureate or master's degree in healthcare administration; or
An individual who has successfully completed an AIT program in another state, if the program is substantially comparable to the AIT program in the State, as determined by the Board.
The preceptor for an AIT shall be currently certified by the Board under Regulation .06 of this chapter.

The preceptor may not be responsible for more than two AITs at any one time. The preceptor shall devote a minimum of 16 hours per week of direct, on-site supervision for each AIT, which may be on an individual or combined basis in the case of two AITs.

The preceptor may be the administrator of record of the facility in which the training is to take place, provided that the preceptor has had a minimum of 30 days of oversight in the facility where the training is to take place immediately prior to beginning the AIT program.
The preceptor may not be the administrator of record for a facility other than the facility designated for training.

A minimum of 80 percent of the training shall occur during 8 consecutive hours for full-time programs or 6 consecutive hours for part-time programs each day (except for regular days off) between the hours of 7 a.m. and 7 p.m.

A minimum of 40 hours per week for full-time or 30 hours per week for part-time shall be devoted to continuous, bona fide training activities which include observing and performing the day-to-day duties of each position, when legally permissible, in the service areas referred to in Regulation .04A(2) of this chapter.
The applicant may spend a maximum of 50 percent of the training in a family-owned or family-operated nursing home, and the remainder of the time shall be spent in another Board-approved facility.
An employee may not be a preceptor for their employer.
Required AIT Reports.
The AIT and preceptor shall maintain a progress report for the training program on the forms provided by the Board for every 3 months of the training program.
The report shall:
Be submitted by the AIT and the preceptor to the Board's office on the dates specified by the Board; and
Include the following:
A detailed description of activity or area covered, or both, and dates of rotation, and, if applicable, an explanation for any changes to the Board-approved rotation schedule;
A detailed analysis of any problems observed, new experiences, insights gained, and the AIT's role in problem solutions; and
The course of instruction outline including signatures from the preceptor, AIT, and department managers to verify that the AIT trained in those departments.
If the reports are not submitted to the Board's office by the date specified by the Board, the AIT shall be considered to have violated the terms of the AIT contract.
Discontinuance of AIT Status in a Nursing Home.
The AIT and the preceptor shall report discontinuance within 10 days to the Board.
Within 10 days of the date of discontinuation, the preceptor shall file a report to the Board detailing the AIT's experience and abilities.
The AIT may fulfill the training requirement in no more than two licensed nursing facilities, with a lapse of no more than 90 days between the two periods of training.
The Board shall issue a certificate of qualification to be a preceptor in the AIT program if the following conditions are met:
The preceptor holds and has held a license from the Board for 1 year or longer;
The proposed preceptor has been satisfactorily employed in nursing home administration for a minimum of 3 years as the nursing home administrator of record;
The proposed preceptor has no disciplinary action pending nor is currently under investigation by the Board;
Individuals seeking certification as preceptors in the AIT program shall submit evidence of the successful completion of the preceptor training course offered by NAB; and

The proposed preceptor has either been employed full time as a nursing home administrator of record for a minimum of 2 of the past 3 years immediately before application to precept or meets the following qualifications:
Works on the same property as the nursing home where the AIT program will be conducted;
Is able to demonstrate to the Board the proposed preceptor’s active, direct, and material management and daily operations of the nursing home; and
Has been actively licensed as a nursing home administrator for a minimum of 5 years immediately before application to precept.
If the proposed preceptor has not precepted an AIT program within the past 5 years, the proposed preceptor shall recertify as a preceptor by completing the preceptor training course offered by NAB.
The Board may disapprove a preceptor for a training program:
If the preceptor has failed to remain in compliance with this chapter; or
At any time for good cause.

The Board, in its discretion, may grant a license by endorsement to practice nursing home administration in the State, upon satisfactory evidence that the endorsement applicant, in addition to the requirements of this section, meets all the qualifications and requirements for a nursing home administrator license set forth in Regulation .02 of this chapter, except that the endorsement applicant is not required to:
Take the NAB exams set forth under Regulation .03 of this chapter; or
Participate in the AIT program that is set forth under Regulation .04 of this chapter.
The endorsement applicant shall:

Possess a valid license as a nursing home administrator, which has not been revoked or suspended in each state from which the applicant has ever received a nursing home administrator license or reciprocal endorsement;
Provide satisfactory evidence of having completed one year as the full-time nursing home administrator of record in a nursing home within the last 5 years; and
Be familiar with State and local health and safety regulations related to nursing homes by evidence of a passing score on the State standards exam.
To be granted a State nursing home administrator license, the endorsement applicant shall possess a nursing home administrator license in other states that shall:
Maintain a system and standard of qualification and examination for a license, which are substantially equivalent to those required by this State; and
Give similar recognition and endorsement to nursing home administrator licenses of this State.
The Board may waive:

The education requirements of COMAR 10.33.02.02B(3), if the endorsement applicant provides satisfactory evidence to the Board that the endorsement applicant is licensed and has practiced as a nursing home administrator for at least 3 years in another state; and

The State standards examination, if the endorsement applicant provides satisfactory evidence to the Board that the endorsement applicant met the requirements of Health Occupations Article, §9-306(b), Annotated Code of Maryland.

As an exception to the licensure requirements in this chapter, a nursing home shall immediately appoint an individual not licensed to practice as a nursing home administrator to act as the interim nursing home administrator if:
A licensed nursing home administrator in the State leaves or is removed from the position as a nursing home administrator by death or other unexpected cause; and
A licensed nursing home administrator in the State is unavailable to fill the position.
The departure of the licensed nursing home administrator specified under §A of this regulation is by unexpected cause if:
The departure occurred suddenly;
The departure was unforeseen; and
There was insufficient time for the nursing home to obtain the services of a nursing home administrator licensed in the State.
The appointed non-licensed individual may begin acting as the interim nursing home administrator upon appointment by the nursing home.
No later than 24 hours after the appointment of the non-licensed individual as interim nursing home administrator, under §A of this regulation, the nursing home shall:
File an application with the Board requesting a provisional license for the non-licensed individual;
Notify the Board of the circumstances involved in the departure of the licensed nursing home administrator;
Notify the Board of the credentials of the non-licensed individual; and
If requested, provide the Board with the acts the nursing home took, or is taking, to hire a nursing home administrator who is licensed in the State.
State and National Criminal History Records Check.
The appointed non-licensed individual shall immediately submit to a criminal history records check, in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §9-302.1, Annotated Code of Maryland.

A criminal history records check is not required if the appointed non-licensed individual is actively licensed by a health occupations board in the State who previously has completed a criminal history records check required for licensure, certification, or registration.

The Board may deny approval of an appointment based on the results of a criminal history records check after consideration of the factors listed in Health Occupations Article, §9–308(b)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland.
Provisional License. The Board may issue a provisional license to the applicant if the Board determines that:
The applicant is of good moral character;
The departure of the licensed nursing home administrator was by unexpected cause; and
The applicant is capable of adequately administering the nursing home for the provisional period.

If the Board grants the application for the provisional nursing home administrator license, the provisional license is in effect for 90 days from the date of the departure of the licensed nursing home administrator. For good cause shown, the Board may extend the provisional license period by 30 days.
Denial of Provisional License.
If the application for a provisional license is denied by the Board, the nursing home may request a meeting with the Board to contest the denial.
The nursing home shall provide the request for a meeting to the Board within 5 business days of the denial.
If the nursing home requests a meeting, the appointed non-licensed individual may remain acting as the interim nursing home administrator until the Board issues a decision.

If the Board denies the application for a provisional license after a meeting contesting the initial denial, the non-licensed individual shall immediately cease acting as the interim nursing home administrator upon receipt of the decision.

If the nursing home does not file a timely request for a meeting with the Board, the non-licensed individual shall cease acting as the interim nursing home administrator within 5 business days of the denial.

If the non-licensed individual is required to cease acting as the interim nursing home administrator under §H of this regulation, and a nursing home administrator licensed in the State remains unavailable to fill the nursing home administrator position, the nursing home may appoint another non-licensed individual as set forth in this regulation.

As a result of §I of this regulation, if the nursing home appoints another non-licensed individual, and a provisional license is granted, the provisional license is in effect for 90 days from the date of the departure of the nursing home administrator licensed in the State, unless the Board extends the provisional license, for good cause shown, for an additional 30 days.
Upon request by the nursing home, for reasonable cause, the Board may extend the 24-hour time period for meeting the requirements of §D of this regulation.
The Board shall send each licensee a renewal notice that states the:
Date on which the current license or current registration expires;
Latest date by which the renewal application and documentation can be received by the Board in order for the renewal license to be issued before the current license expires; and
Amount of the renewal fee as specified in COMAR 10.33.05.02D.

At least 30 days before the current license expires, the Board shall send the renewal notice by electronic means to the last known electronic mail address or first-class mail to the physical address of the licensee.
Licensees shall satisfactorily complete the minimum continuing education requirements set forth under COMAR 10.33.04.

Licensees shall complete an implicit bias and structural racism training program approved by the Cultural and Linguistic Health Care Professional Competency Program in accordance with Health-General Article, §20-1306, Annotated Code of Maryland, for an applicant’s first renewal after April 1, 2026.
The Board shall reinstate an individual whose license has expired if the individual:
Meets the renewal requirements of this chapter and Health Occupations Article, §9-312, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Pays the reinstatement fee as specified under COMAR 10.33.05.02D; and
Satisfactorily completes the minimum continuing education requirements set forth under COMAR 10.33.04.01.

A previously licensed nursing home administrator who fails to apply for licensure reinstatement within 5 years after the expiration date of the license shall meet the requirements for a new license in effect at the time of the request in order to be licensed to practice as a nursing home administrator in the State.
In accordance with Health Occupations Article, §9-312.1, Annotated Code of Maryland, a request by an active licensee to transfer a license to inactive status shall be granted upon receipt of the:
Completed Board-approved inactive status application; and
Payment of the required, non-refundable, biennial inactive status fee set forth in COMAR 10.33.05.02D.
An individual:
May apply for inactive status only if the individual’s license is still active at the time the inactive status application request is made;
Shall renew and pay the biennial inactive status fee during each renewal period; and
Is not authorized to and may not practice as a nursing home administrator in the State while on inactive status.
Reactivation.
The Board shall reactivate the license of a licensee who is on inactive status if the licensee:
Completes an application form for reactivation of the license before expiration of the 2-year term of inactive status on the form required by the Board;
Complies with the renewal requirements in effect at the time the licensee seeks to reactivate the license;
Meets the continuing education requirements set by the Board;
Has not practiced as a nursing home administrator in the State while on inactive status;
Pays all appropriate fees set by the Board under COMAR 10.33.05.02D;
Has been on inactive status for less than 5 years; and
Is otherwise entitled to be licensed.
Before the Board may reactivate the license of an individual who has been on inactive status for 5 years or more, the individual shall:
Submit a new online application;
Pay all appropriate fees set by the Board under COMAR 10.33.05.02D;
Complete a 100-hour Board–approved course in healthcare administration or health administration;
Pass the State standards exam for nursing home administrators; and
Submit satisfactory evidence of having completed a State and national criminal history records check in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §9–302.1, Annotated Code of Maryland.

A nursing home administrator whose inactive status expires before the license is reactivated shall meet the reinstatement requirements set forth in Health Occupations Article, §9-312, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Board is not required to consider an application that is incomplete.
The applicant shall submit to the Board any additional relevant documentation requested by the Board if the Board determines the application documentation received is incomplete or insufficient.
The Board may hold an incomplete application for a license for up to 1 year from the date of receipt.
After 1 year from the date of receipt, the Board shall close a pending application that is incomplete.
If an application has been closed under §D of this regulation, to obtain a license the applicant shall submit a new application fee and otherwise comply with all applicable license requirements.

section.heading: Display of License.
section.text: Each individual licensed as a nursing home administrator in the State shall display printed verification of licensure in a conspicuous place in the office or place of business or employment of the licensee.

section.heading: Change of Mailing Address, Legal Name, or Email Address.

para.text: A licensed nursing home administrator shall give the Board written or electronic notice within 30 days of a change of:
Mailing address;
Legal name; or
Email address.
