Health-General Article, §§2-104 and 19-1809; Health Occupations Article, §§1-212, 1-602—1-609, 9-205, 9-313—9-316.1, 9-3A-11—9-3A-17, and
9-401—9-407; State Government Article, §§10-201—10-226; Annotated Code of Maryland
Effective date: January 19, 2026 (53:1 Md. R 22)

section.heading: Disclosure for Compelling Public Purpose.
section.text: The Board’s Executive Director may find that a compelling public purpose warrants disclosure of information in a certification, licensing, or investigative file, whether or not there has been a request for the information and may disclose the information under the following circumstances:

para.text: The information concerns possible criminal activity and is disclosed to a federal, state, or local law enforcement or prosecutorial official or authority;

The information concerns a possible violation of law and is disclosed to a federal, state, or local authority that has jurisdiction over the person or government entity whose conduct may be a violation, and the information disclosed is limited to information relevant to the possible violation by that individual; or

The information concerns conduct by a person or government entity which the Board’s Executive Director reasonably believes may pose a risk to the public health, safety, or welfare and is disclosed to a law enforcement authority, administrative official, or agency that regulates the individual, or to a hospital or other healthcare facility where the individual has privileges.

section.heading: Other Disclosures.
section.text: This chapter does not prevent or limit the ability of the Board to disclose general licensing information as provided in General Provisions Article, §4-333, Annotated Code of Maryland, or any information which the Board may otherwise disclose by law.

annotations.annotation: General Provisions Article, §4-333; Health Occupations Article, §9-205; Annotated Code of Maryland
Effective date: January 19, 2026 (53:1 Md. R 22)

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“CDC Guidelines” means the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Guidelines for Infection Control in Dental Health-Care Settings—2003.
“Practice dentistry” has the meaning stated in Health Occupations Article, §4-101, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Private dental office” has the meaning stated in Health Occupations Article, §4-308, Annotated Code of Maryland.

“Standard and transmission based precautions” means the minimum infection control prevention practices that apply to all patient care, regardless of suspected or confirmed infection status of the patient, in any setting where health care is delivered.

“Supervising dentist” means a dentist licensed in the State, including a solo practitioner, who is responsible for all infection control activities within a private dental office as set forth in this chapter.

section.heading: Incorporation by Reference.
section.text: Guidelines for Infection Control in Dental Health-Care Settings—2003 (Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR): Recommendations and Reports, 2003; v. 52; no. 17, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC, Atlanta, GA)) is incorporated by reference.

para.text: Each owner of a private dental office shall designate a licensed dentist to be the supervising dentist for the private dental office.
A supervising dentist designated under §A of this regulation shall:
Complete the registration required by the Board on a form provided by the Board; and
Be responsible for all infection control activities within the private dental office.

If a supervising dentist for a private dental office relinquishes the supervising dentist’s responsibilities under §B(2) of this regulation, for any reason, the owner of the private dental office shall immediately designate an interim supervising dentist who shall be responsible for all infection control within the private dental office until a new supervising dentist for the private dental office registers with the Board.
An interim supervising dentist may remain an interim supervising dentist for no more than 45 calendar days prior to the registration of a subsequent supervising dentist.
The responsibilities of a supervising dentist set forth in this regulation is not considered the practice of dentistry.

This regulation may not be construed to prevent an unlicensed individual from assisting with regulatory compliance consistent with Health Occupations Article, §4-103(e)(12), Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Board may charge a fee not to exceed the fee set forth in COMAR 10.44.20 for the registration and any subsequent registrations of supervising dentists.

section.heading: Display of Registration.
section.text: The owner of a private dental office shall display the name of the supervising dentist and the name of the interim supervising dentist, if applicable, conspicuously in the office on the form provided by the Board.

para.text: The supervising dentist in a private dental office shall be responsible for the following infection control activities:
Adherence to the CDC Guidelines in their individual capacity as described in Regulation .06 of this chapter;
The provision and accessibility of sufficient and appropriate:
Personal protective equipment including but not limited to:
Gloves;
Masks;
Eyewear; and
Gowns;
Hand soaps and hand scrubs;
Puncture-resistant sharps containers located in close proximity to where they are to be used;
Products for cleaning and disinfecting environmental surfaces that are approved by the Environmental Protection Agency or its successor;
Periodic water quality testing to ensure that water meets Environmental Protection Agency regulatory standards for drinking water;
Sterilization monitoring of reusable dental equipment and instruments in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions for use, including:
Biological spore testing;
Chemical monitoring; and
Mechanical monitoring;
Maintenance of a biohazard waste removal contract for the office; and
Signage for patient waiting areas for those exhibiting symptoms of respiratory infection.

In addition to the activities set forth in §A of this regulation, a supervising dentist shall be responsible for the training of clinical staff upon hire and before engaging in clinical duties, and at minimum, annually.
The training of clinical staff shall include training regarding:
Standard and transmission based precautions;
Hand hygiene;
Personal protective equipment;
Respiratory hygiene/cough etiquette;
Sharps safety;
Safe injection practices;
Sterilizing and disinfecting clinical contact and housekeeping surfaces;
Spore testing;
Water quality testing; and
The Occupational Safety and Health Administration Bloodborne Pathogens Standard as set forth in 29 C.F.R. §1910.1030.

A supervising dentist shall ensure that evidence-based written policies and procedures, based upon current CDC Guidelines, regulatory requirements, and other relevant guidance documents, are developed, maintained, and readily available for review by the office’s clinical staff.
The policies and procedures referred to in §D of this regulation shall be updated either annually or more often if appropriate, to reflect new evidence, guidelines, or regulatory requirements.
A supervising dentist shall maintain adequate written records of the activities set forth in §§A—E of this regulation in each office for which the records apply.

A supervising dentist who practices clinical dentistry shall, for their own practice of dentistry, be responsible for all infection control activities in the dental office including those activities that are not considered structural infection control or those that do not impact the entirety of the private dental office.

section.heading: Individual Dentist Responsibilities.
section.text: Notwithstanding the responsibilities of a supervising dentist set forth in Regulation .05 of this chapter, an individual dentist who is not a supervising dentist shall be responsible for infection control activities in the control of the individual dentist including:

para.text: Use of adequate personal protective equipment; and
Sterilization of instruments.

section.heading: Violations.
section.text: Violations of this chapter constitutes unprofessional conduct and may result in disciplinary action against a dentist as set forth in Health Occupations Article, §4-315, Annotated Code of Maryland.

annotations.annotation: Health Occupations Article, §§4-104 and 4-205(c)(1)(v), Annotated Code of Maryland
Effective date: January 19, 2026 (53:1 Md. R. 23))

para.text: An out-of-State institution seeking initial approval may not operate in Maryland, do business, recruit or enroll students, begin instruction, or promote advanced publicity through advertisements, announcements, or other similar media on proposed courses or programs to be offered in Maryland until it obtains approval from the Secretary in accordance with this chapter.

The Secretary's approval to operate in Maryland, if granted, shall be for a period of 1 year and may be renewable on an annual basis for the first 5 years of operation in Maryland, and thereafter for an extended period of time up to 5 years.
An out-of-State institution that has received a certificate of approval to operate in Maryland may not add a new program until it has complied with §D(3) of this regulation.
Procedures to Apply for Initial Approval to Operate in Maryland.

To receive initial approval to operate in Maryland, the chief executive officer shall submit to the Secretary, on the forms provided, a written application for authorization to offer one or more postsecondary educational courses or programs in a specific location in Maryland. The completed application and all supportive documentation shall be provided at least 5 months before the out-of-State institution proposes to begin operation.
An institution shall submit a non-refundable application fee in the amount of:
$7,500 for up to two degree programs; and
An additional $850 for each degree program over two programs.
The application to offer degree and certificate programs shall include:
Identification of the institution;
The specific address, if known, or the geographical location of proposed operation, including, at a minimum, the county or city, with the specific address to be provided when known;
Proposed start date and term of operation;
Identification of authorized representatives;
Board of trustees resolution of financial solvency;
Except as provided in §D(4)(a) of this regulation, certificate of incorporation as a foreign (out-of State) corporation from the Department of Assessments and Taxation;
Institutional accreditation status with an organization recognized as an accrediting agency by the U.S. Department of Education to grant institutional accreditation;
Copies of awards to be granted;
Programmatic data, including the degree or certificate, the curriculum, and proposed schedule of classes;
A detailed and accurate description of the proposed programs and operations including:
All degree and certificate programs to be offered by the institution;
A description of the objectives of each degree and certificate program including the mode of instructional delivery;
A description of the student population to be served; and
A description of a teach-out plan allowing enrolled students to complete their program if the institution decides to cease operation in Maryland;

Evidence of a critical and compelling regional or Statewide need and demand for specific academic degree programs in a specific geographic region of the State in accordance with Regulation .06 of this chapter;
Data projecting market demand and the availability of openings in the job market to be served by each new program;
Qualification of instructors and staff;
Library resources;
Certificate of compliance with fire and safety codes;
Copies of advertisements; and
If applicable, a letter of sponsorship from the employer or institution that is requesting the out-of-State institution to offer a program in Maryland.
Certificate of Incorporation.
A public institution is not required to submit a certificate of incorporation as a foreign corporation.
A business entity affiliated with a public institution is required to submit a certificate of incorporation.

The institution may apply to offer courses only if the full complement of courses comprise not more than 3 courses or 9 credits of a degree or certificate program. The application to offer courses shall include:
Identification of the institution;
The specific address, if known, or the geographic location of proposed operation, including, at a minimum, the county or city, with the specific address to be provided when known;
Proposed start date and term of operation;
Certificate of incorporation as a foreign (out-of-State) corporation, if required by State law;
Institutional accreditation status with an organization recognized as an accrediting agency by the U.S. Department of Education to grant institutional accreditation;
Programmatic data, including the degree or certificate, the curriculum, and the proposed schedule of classes;
A description of the objectives of each course including the mode of instructional delivery;
A description of the student population to be served;

Evidence of a critical and compelling regional or Statewide need and demand for specific academic degree programs in a specific geographic region of the State in accordance with Regulation .06 of this chapter;
Qualification of instructors and staff;
Certificate of compliance with fire and safety codes; and
If applicable, a letter of sponsorship from the employer or institution that is requesting the institution to offer a course in Maryland.
Application to Operate in Maryland as a Closed Site Out-of-State Institution.

An application to offer degree and certificate programs as a closed-site institution shall include all of the application requirements specified in §D(3) of this regulation. An application to offer not more than 3 courses or 9 credits of a degree or certificate program as a closed-site institution shall include all of the application requirements specified in §D(5) of this regulation.

In addition, the institution shall supply a memorandum of understanding from the Maryland entity sponsoring the institution. The memorandum of understanding shall specify that the institution is operating as a closed-site and that courses are offered solely for its own employees.
Application Review, Notice, and Period for Comments and Objections.

Upon submission by an out-of-State institution of the application and documentation required by §D of this regulation, the Secretary shall review the application and documentation to ensure that the institution has satisfied the requirements of this chapter.
Upon receipt of a complete application and documentation, the Secretary shall inform all institutions of higher education and segments of higher education of the proposal.
A 30-day period for comments and objections shall be allowed.
Any institution of higher education or segment of higher education desiring to raise an objection shall do so during the 30-day comment period.
The Secretary shall consider all comments and objections received before making the final decision.
The Secretary may not consider an objection raised after the 30-day period.
The Secretary may ask the applicant institution for additional information in response to comments and objections received.
The 30-day period for comments and objections does not apply to a closed-site institution.
Secretary's Grant of Approval to Operate in Maryland.
The Secretary shall grant the certificate of approval to the out-of-State institution to operate in Maryland on such conditions as may be considered appropriate, if the Secretary is satisfied that:
The application and documentation submitted by the institution is in compliance with this chapter and the institution is in compliance with this chapter;
The institution is fully accredited by an organization recognized as an accrediting agency by the U.S. Department of Education to grant institutional accreditation; and
The programs to be offered in Maryland are similar to programs offered at its main or primary campus, unless the Secretary finds that the institution has provided sufficient justification otherwise.
The Secretary shall notify the chief executive officer of the institution in writing of the official action taken by the Secretary.
Secretary's Denial of Approval to Operate in Maryland.
If the Secretary is not satisfied that an out-of-State institution is in compliance with this chapter, the Secretary shall issue a notice of deficiencies and deny approval to the institution.

Within 20 days of receipt of a notice of deficiencies, the institution denied approval to operate in Maryland may request a hearing before the Commission as provided in Education Article, §11-202(f), Annotated Code of Maryland.

The hearing before the Commission shall be conducted in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act, State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 13B.04.01.
If the institution requests a hearing, the Commission may refer the hearing to the Office of Administrative Hearings.
After the hearing in §G(3) of this regulation, the Commission may take the following action:
Grant approval to operate;
Deny approval to operate; or
Remand the case to the Secretary for further action as directed by the Commission.
If the institution does not file a timely request for a hearing on the notice of deficiencies, the Secretary's decision becomes final.
Completed Application and Documentation.
An application is complete as of the day on which an out-of-State institution submits documentation satisfactory to the Secretary that the institution has completed the application process.

If the Secretary has neither issued a certificate of approval nor a written notice of deficiency within 6 months of the completed application, the institution may request a hearing before the Commission to determine whether a certificate of approval shall be issued.
The request shall be made within 20 days of the expiration of the 6-month period.
The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act, State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 13B.04.01.
Judicial Review.

An out-of-State institution that is denied a certificate of approval by the Commission after a hearing granted under §G or H of this regulation has the right to judicial review provided by State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The decision of the Commission is presumed correct and the institution has the burden of proving otherwise.
The Commission shall be a party to the proceeding.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Commission” means the Maryland Higher Education Commission.
“Cybersecurity program” means a credit-bearing degree or certificate program that:
Is approved by the Commission under Education Article, §11-206, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Has been identified by the Secretary as directly relevant to cybersecurity and published on the Commission website.
“Director” means the Executive Director of the Office.
“Education expenses” mean:
Tuition and mandatory fees;
Costs of room and board.
“Eligible institution” means:
A community college in the State;
A public senior higher education institution in the State; or
A private nonprofit institution of higher education in the State that:
Is approved to operate by the Commission under Education Article §11-202, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
May operate without a Certificate of Approval from the Commission under §11-202.1 (a), Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Extenuating circumstances” mean a documented disability, including pregnancy, or a documented extended illness, that prevents a recipient from fulfilling a scholarship requirement.
“Full-time” means:
Enrollment at an eligible institution at least 12 credits per semester in a certificate or undergraduate degree program; at the time of certification of the Scholarship; or
Classification by an eligible institution as a full-time student in a graduate certificate, graduate degree, or doctoral degree program at the time of certification of the Scholarship.
“Local Educational Agency” has the meaning stated in 20 U.S.C. §1401 (19).
“Office” means the Office of Student Financial Assistance within the Maryland Higher Education Commission.
“Part-time” means:

Enrollment at an eligible institution in at least 6 credits, but fewer than 12 credits, per semester in an undergraduate certificate or degree program at the time of certification of the Scholarship; or
Classification by an eligible institution as a part-time student in a graduate certificate or degree program at the time of certification of the Scholarship:
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Higher Education.
“Scholarship” means a Cybersecurity Public Service Scholarship under this chapter.
Subject to the State budget, the Office annually shall determine a student’s eligibility to receive a scholarship.
An applicant is eligible for a scholarship if the applicant:
Is enrolled full-time or part-time at an eligible institution in a cybersecurity program;
Has earned a minimum of 25 percent of the credits required to complete the cybersecurity program;
Has maintained a cumulative grade point average of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale;
Has not received a federal CyberCorps Scholarship for Service, regardless of whether the applicant has applied for a federal CyberCorps Scholarship for Service;
Either:
Attends a public eligible institution, and has been determined eligible for in-State tuition by the institution; or
Attends a private nonprofit eligible institution, and would qualify for in-State tuition under the provisions of Education Article, Title 15, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Timely files an application and any required supporting documentation with the Office.
A student shall apply annually to the Office to be eligible for a scholarship in the form prescribed by the Office.
Time of Submission. An application and required documentation received by the Office after July1 is untimely and shall not be considered.
An applicant shall submit the following required documentation:
Copy of the applicant’s official college or university transcript;

Proof from the eligible institution that the applicant is enrolled full-time and is within 3 years from graduation in a cybersecurity program, or is enrolled part-time and is within 6 years from graduation in a cybersecurity program; and
Certification from the institution that the applicant has not received or applied for a Federal CyberCorps Scholarship for Service.
Subject to Regulation .06 of this chapter, a scholarship shall be renewed for a subsequent year if the applicant continues to meet the requirements of Regulation .03 of this chapter.
A recipient enrolled full-time may receive a scholarship for a maximum of 3 years.
A recipient enrolled part-time may receive a scholarship for a maximum of 6 years.
An annual scholarship for a full-time student shall be in the amount prescribed by the Director, and shall be appropriately prorated by the Director for the part-time status of the recipient.
The amount of an annual scholarship may not exceed the recipient’s education expenses.
Renewal Awards. Priority of scholarships shall be given to prior year recipients who remain eligible under Regulation .05 of this chapter.
If funds remain after awards are made to students under §A of this regulation, eligible applicants shall be ranked on the basis of cumulative grade point average.
Grades for credits earned for an applicant attending a public or private nonprofit institution 3 years prior to graduation shall be used to calculate the cumulative grade point average.
Awards shall be made to applicants based on cumulative grade point average ranked highest to lowest. Awards shall be issued until the total funds appropriated for the program have been depleted.
Recipients shall be notified through the Maryland College Aid Processing System (MDCAPS) of the scholarship awards.
A recipient shall accept the award online through MDCAPS by the date specified in the award notice, or the award shall be forfeited.
Eligible applicants who do not receive an award shall be notified and placed on a waiting list and considered if funds become available.
Verification. The Office shall verify that the applicant:
Meets the grade point average requirement;
Is:
Enrolled full-time and is within 3 years from graduating in a cybersecurity program,or
Enrolled part-time and is within 6 years from graduating in a cybersecurity program; and
Is not a recipient of a Federal CyberCorps Scholarship for Service award.
Payment. Eligible institutions shall certify on billing rosters provided by the Office that the recipient is:
Eligible for in-State tuition;
Maintaining a grade point average of at least a 3.0 on a 4.0 scale;
Enrolled full-time or part-time in a cybersecurity program;
Maintaining satisfactory academic progress toward a degree; and
Maintaining the standards of the institution.
Full-Time Employment. For purposes of this regulation, “full-time employment” means employment for at least 35 hours per week.
Use of Scholarship. A scholarship shall be used solely for education expenses to attend an eligible institution.

As a precondition of receiving a scholarship, a recipient shall provide a promissory note and shall enter into a written agreement with the Commission, in the form and manner prescribed by the Office, requiring the recipient to:
Earn credit as a full-time or part-time student;
Complete the cybersecurity program for which the recipient received the scholarship; and
Perform the service obligation described in §D of this regulation.
Service Obligation.
For each semester that the recipient receives a scholarship, the recipient shall, for the time period specified in this section:
Maintain full-time employment in the State in the cybersecurity field for a:
Local educational agency;
Public high school;
Community college; or
A unit of State, county, city or municipal government; or
Teach full-time in the State in an education program that is directly relevant to cybersecurity in a:
Public high school; or
Community college.
A full-time student shall perform the service obligation for 6 months for each semester the student received the scholarship.
A part-time student shall perform the service obligation for 3 months for each semester the student received the scholarship.
Regardless of whether a recipient was enrolled as a full-time student or part-time student, the work obligation for the recipient shall not exceed 3 years for full-time employment.

section.heading: Failure to Meet Conditions of Scholarship.

para.text: Except as provided in §C of this regulation, if the recipient breaches the terms or conditions of the agreement or note under Regulation .09 of this chapter, including the failure to perform the service obligation, the scholarship shall convert to a student loan payable to the State.

Interest on the loan shall be charged at an interest rate equal to the interest rate established by the United States Department of Education for the Federal Stafford Loan on the first day of July of each year.
Interest may not accrue prior to notification to the Office of a recipient’s graduation or termination from an institution of higher education.
Repayment may be prorated if the recipient partially fulfills the service obligation.

Except as otherwise provided in this regulation, repayment shall be made to the State within 6 years after the repayment period begins, and shall follow a repayment schedule established by the Office.

section.heading: Deferment of the Service Obligation and Repayment.

para.text: Recipients shall seek eligible employment aggressively within the State.
A recipient may request that the service obligation be deferred during the time the recipient is:
Enrolled full-time in an undergraduate or graduate course of study that would further their career in cybersecurity, at any institution of higher education in the State;
On a temporary leave of absence, approved by the employer in the required employment field, for a period not to exceed 12 months;
Temporarily disabled in a manner that substantially impairs the recipient’s ability to perform the service obligation, for a period not to exceed 3 years;
Unable to maintain employment, for a period not to exceed 12 months, because the recipient must care for a spouse or child who is disabled;
Assigned military duty outside of the State, not to exceed 4 years; or
Married to a spouse assigned military duty outside of the State, not to exceed 4 years.
A recipient’s deferment request shall include satisfactory supporting documentation, consisting of the following, as appropriate:
Certification by the institution that the recipient has returned to a full-time or part-time course of study at an institution of post-secondary education in the State;
Certification by the employer that the recipient is on a temporary approved leave of absence;
A sworn affidavit by a qualified physician that the recipient is temporarily disabled in a manner that substantially impairs the recipient’s ability to perform the service obligation;
A sworn affidavit by a qualified physician that the recipient is unable to maintain employment because the recipient must care for a spouse or child who is disabled; or
A copy of military orders.
The Office shall review all documentation, determine if the deferment conditions have been met and, if so, determine the deferment period.
During the period of an approved deferment, a recipient need not make scholarship repayments and interest does not accrue.

section.heading: Determinations of the Office.
section.text: Decisions of the Office under this chapter regarding award eligibility, recipient selection, and deferment or waiver of the service obligation are final and not subject to additional review.
